The internal politics have been stirred by the busy work of the Parliament in the past few days, since the law about the expulsion of Jews from Bulgaria has been discussed. The following event occurred: the Germans asked the Bulgarian government, supposedly based on the suggestion from the local German delegate, to deport over 30,000 Jews altogether. Out of the total, eight of them were supposed to be moved to Palestine and the rest to the General Government. The Deputy Speaker of the Assembly, Peshev, stood against the proposed law and managed to collect 36 out of 46 present members of the parliamentary majority, thus the proposed law would have been dismissed. However, Filov took a counter-measure. He contacted all the members of the parliamentary majority by telegraph to come in and declare a general distrust in Peshev. This was declared by an overwhelming majority in the evening of the 26th the given month. Thus, the law on the expulsion of Jews will be carried out. It is being said that Peshev did not approve of the way the Germans deal with the Jews awaiting deportations. That their ways are inhuman, they “throw 60 souls” to cattle wagons with only one bucket of water and one for the excrements while these Jews travel in sealed wagons. The Deputy Speaker Peshev used to be a bank director before and he got that position – according to the legionary elements – thanks to being a Freemason. Supposedly, that is also the reason he was named a Deputy Speaker

of the Assembly. The declaration of distrust enforced Filov's position, although it is being claimed that the king did not publicly hide his disagreement with the events happening in the Parliament and neither with the character of the anti-Jewish measures the government was planning to carry out.
